author: KingIshmael
body: Big institutions tend to go long when they hold sizable stakes. They almost have too. If an institution like BR or Berkshire were to randomly dump a stonk without a solid justification, the SEC could/ would fine them for market manipulation because of the ripples made in the share holder confidence and market indexes. Large firms have to generally have a packet of DD for every move they make.

author: HuntingBears1
body: Good post, thanks. Little quibble: is what you describe as literal pump and dumps, actual pump and dumps? A pump and dump is when you pump up a stock and then sell it when everyone’s bought in. You’re talking about BR buying some stocks and selling others. That’s not a pump and dump.

author: gapuzl
body:
Depends on the stock and why is it falling. If you believe it will go up then don't wait it goes lower. Just set yourself limits when do you add more. 

What I personally do is, I wait for 20-30% drop if this happens (example m....med) I sell all so I get back the lost tax I have already paid with some profit taking from other stocks (located in Austria). Then I immediately buy back + invest the returned tax + add some of my funds. 

It works wonders. Managed to Rebuy m..med just before the latest bull run. Already up 100% with the add on part of the holdings. 

Just my tactic. 

BR,
G

author: greensymbiote
body:
Because those are the primary fintechs in the same space. Some of which have slower growth, smaller margins or no profit at all while still commanding higher multiples. Unlike most fintechs Paysafe has a big exposure in live sporting events and brick and mortar retail which was completely shut down in 2020 due to Covid.  In a call with analysts they discussed their decision to keep revenue growth projections in line with the fintech market at large which is 11%.  They are deliberately leaving their M&A plans out of their projections as well as their expected growth in US igaming.  

This is in keeping with Chairman of the Board Bill Foley's style which has been described as under promise and over deliver.  Many are betting on the growth of this company based on Foley's proven track record.  In just the last five years, Foley and his team grew Ceridian 3.3X ($4.2B to $14B), Dun & Bradstreet 5.6X ($2B to $11.3B) and Black Knight 8.7X ($1.6B to $14B). He also grew Fidelity National Information Services 36.4X ($2.5Billion to over $91Billion). Foley recently said, “Those characteristics of FIS are right in line with what we plan on doing with Paysafe.”

author: redditspeechcensor
body:
In 2020, I collected dividends from the following holdings that I have since liquidated this year: ARR, DOW, EPD, GEO, GIS, IBM, IRM, JPM, MMP, PM, SKT, STX, T, TNL, VZ, VER, XOM.

In 2020, I collected dividends from the following holdings that I continue to hold: EPR, MO, SMHB.

So why did I sell some of the best dividend stocks the market has to offer after literally buying them in March/April of 2020 at the bottom?  Great question.  Maybe the better question is why did I keep those 3?  

The answer is because I still see great share price growth value ahead of both EPR and MO though for different reasons and the SMHB yield (based on pre covid historicals) could yield as high as 72% based on my purchase price.  Though I only collected 10.14% in 2020 and 6.82% so far in 2021.  EPR has yet to reinstate its dividend and I fully expect that when they do, their share price will see a large upward move.  And MO?  Well... it is my opinion that Altria is uniquely positioned to be the largest player in the budding legalized marijuana industry in the USA.  So obviously I will hold that until such a time when that new industry can be realized and profited from and pocket a 9.54% yield (2020 actual) in the meantime.

But the reality is, I didn't buy some of the best dividend paying companies at the 2020 bottom because I wanted the dividend.  In fact... dividend investing is mostly a waste of time unless you plan on buying and forgetting... in which case... it still is since you'd be better off in an index fund.

author: checkdateusercreated
body:
INTC is the only one that offers a dividend. It's an aristocrat.

That literally binds their majority shareholder interest to the dividend income, with the share price having a minor role in everyday share movement.

EDIT: Just look at IBM. I was looking at buying it for $100 in last year's crash. It rebounded, like a lot of things, but it didn't grow uncontrollably like so many stocks did last year. Instead, it just hung out at $125 all year. Dividend aristocracy.

Why would they do that unless the product itself did things Watson couldn't?

The tech is there, but getting people to essentially change ERPs is a slog. PLTR will eat "dumb" ERPs like SAP for breakfast.

author: musicafishionado
body:
If Nvidia does acquire ARM (highly unlikely) China would be blocked from making chips and they're not gonna react kindly. Take that as you will.

There is nothing stopping Intel and AMD from producing ARM chips except for themselves. They already have the licenses and will begin developing when ARM is past its infancy in the data center world. Let deeper pockets be the pioneers, let all the software transitions happen (x86 software is not compatible with ARM), then poach their engineers. Intel and AMD are sitting back and letting AWS and Apple try their hand at ARM on purpose.

IBM thrived on providing services that were being phased out. x86 isn't going to be phased out this decade and Intel will begin ARM chip production for clients in 3 years. IBM is dying, Intel is 3 years away from the start of unrivaled growth and has potential to eventually surpass TSMC as the industry leader in chip production thanks to the gov/mil backing within 20 years.

If you're looking for big gains in the next 2-6 years Intel is probably not the stock for you. It's at a 13 P/E ratio because people perceive it like IBM which is fine with me, I'll keep adding.

No clue what TSMC will plan to do after 3nm to prevent stagnation. For now they are the leader but physics doesn't let you go smaller than 3nm, possibly 2nm. At 3 times less earnings per dollar than Intel and lacking vertical integration... I'll happily put my dollars to work in Intel.

author: Ironleg01
body:
There are still reasonably valued equities. Mostly your usual value names, some older tech companies and there are few currently hated companies. 
Value ones are some defence names like GD or RTX, I think they are still cheap, there are others too. Then old tech companies (but not necessarily bad ones) are HPE, JNPR, CSCO and few others. Finally hated names (I love buying hated but good companies for cheap) are INTC, GM and few others. There are some special situations too (like VRSK still hasn't fully recovered) and internationally there are interesting equities as well priced cheap. Popular names are expensive but they are popular so... But if you look outside of what people talk about on Reddit you can find some value.

author: dr3amboy3657
body:
Cramer said it once on taxes.  Don’t worry about not paying the taxes so much, the market might take care of that for you.  What that means is that say your stock is @100 and you sell now and pay 35% in taxes or hold it and the stock goes down to 70 anyway.  

Now, the example is too simple but that’s the concept.  I like what the other OP said to reset your cost basis every now and then so it becomes more manageable.  It has become a huge problem for me too.   I too have massive long LGTC >500k on a stock that I’m not sure I want to hold for the next 5 years just so I can sell ~100k a year to reduce taxes.

You say TODAY you want to hold MSFT for a long time but at some point, you will have to pay the taxes.  MSFT might not be around when you retire in 20-30 years.  Just because MSFT has been doing well for the last 5 years doesn’t mean it will do well the next 25.   What if you had massive capital gains in Yahoo, Enron, Xom, Cisco, juniper, ibm, or GME(lol)?   Some are long gone and some have became dead money for years.

author: ThisPomelo4
body:
Your analysis is probably true for delta, but the problem with playing those names using vol is that the IV is higher. Options trading is most useful when you get the gamma cheap while also calling the direction right.

I'm buying INTC 23Apr 70c because resistance at 65 has kept IV muted. My bet is that INTC will break through that resistance on 6Apr or 23Apr. I hate talking in terms of resistance in general, but looking at the long-term chart as well as price action in the morning after the Intel Unleashed event, it certainly seems like you'd need a big catalyst to justify a breakout beyond 65. I'd probably play those profits -- if any -- into AMD puts through to May, because I think hedge fund selling will take place when Lisa Su inevitably acknowledges the incorrectness of her prediction that supply "tightness" would clear up by 2H21.

I also believe that the Archegos liquidation is another sign that correlated hedge fund losses will spell disaster for the market. We saw this already with GME and the other short-squeeze names. Chipmakers like to lay out their capex as close to production ramp-up as possible, which means that LRCX/AMAT/ASML/KLIC/KLAC/CAJ/etc won't book profits immediately even if billions of dollars are allocated to the roadmap. So I'm waiting for a big selloff this summer to get into those names as a long-term position. May try to play that selloff using hedgie favorites and names that have a lot of room to fall. ARKK, TSLA, TSM, NVDA come to mind. TSM seems counterintuitive but you get the added potential catalyst of Chinese brinkmanship as well as a deepening of the water supply woes.

I mention CAJ because it gives a good read on DUV demand. Their equipment segment had a lot of profit growth last quarter. But it's not as good a play as the others because only a fifth of its revenue comes from that segment.
